review.title: Review of Fall Detection Techniques: A Data Availability Perspective
review.abstract: A fall is an abnormal activity that occurs rarely; however, missing to identify falls can have serious health and safety implications on an individual. Due to the rarity of occurrence of falls, there may be insufficient or no training data available for them. Therefore, standard supervised machine learning methods may not be directly applied to handle this problem. In this paper, we present a taxonomy for the study of fall detection from the perspective of availability of fall data. The proposed taxonomy is independent of the type of sensors used and specific feature extraction/selection methods. The taxonomy identifies different categories of classification methods for the study of fall detection based on the availability of their data during training the classifiers. Then, we present a comprehensive literature review within those categories and identify the approach of treating a fall as an abnormal activity to be a plausible research direction. We conclude our paper by discussing several open research problems in the field and pointers for future research.

metadata.title: Review of Fall Detection Techniques: A Data Availability Perspective

sections.text: A fall is an abnormal activity that rarely occurs; however, the lack of identification of falls can have serious effects on the health and safety of an individual. Due to the rarity of the occurrence of falls, they have insufficient or no training data available to them. Therefore, standard supervised machine learning methods cannot be applied directly to this problem. In this paper, we present a taxonomy for studying fall detection from the perspective of the availability of case data. The proposed taxonomy is independent of the type of sensors used and specific methods for extracting / selecting traits. Taxonomy identifies different categories of classification methods for studying fall detection based on the availability of their data during classifier training. Subsequently, we present a comprehensive literature review within these categories and identify the approach of treating a fall as an abnormal activity as a plausible direction of research. We conclude our work by discussing several open research issues in the field and discussing them for future research.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it has never come as far as it has this year.

sections.heading: 2. Survey of Existing Literature Review on Fall Detection

sections.heading: 2.1. Analysis
sections.text: We observe several recurring issues that occur consistently in all such work that we have previously discussed: • There is no standard fall detection methodology in terms of the type of sensors, feature engineering, or machine learning techniques that replace other methods or are consistently better than others. • Many of the above surveys note that techniques based on fixed thresholds for sensor measurements, while easy to implement and mathematically inexpensive, are very difficult to generalize between different people and do not provide a good balance between false positives and false negatives [5]. • Many of these surveys reveal the complete lack of a reference framework, publicly available data sets, and almost no access to real case data to validate and compare them with other methods. • Most of the surveys discussed above review fall detection research that requires sufficient data for falls and adequate foreknowledge and understanding of falls to occur, so it is a very rare event.

sections.heading: 4. Literature Review
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1. Sufficient data for falls
sections.text: Most research in the field of fall detection focuses on the application of monitored classification methods. In this paper, such techniques are not reviewed and interested readers can refer to the work cited in Section 2. Several studies on fall detection are based on swelling techniques [36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 38], where raw or processed sensor data is compared with one or more predefined thresholds to detect a fall (see Taxonomy (I) b in Figure 1). Most of these techniques require training data for falls and use knowledge from other areas or data analysis techniques to calculate thresholds for their identification. The problem with swelling techniques for fall detection is that it is very difficult to adapt thresholds to new types of falls and generalize them between different people [43, 5]. More information on these methods can be found in the surveys discussed in Section 2.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. One-Class Classification
sections.text: When sufficient case data is available, single-class classifiers can be trained on falls to reject normal activities (see taxonomy (I) c in Figure 1). However, in realistic environments, such a strategy is highly unlikely, as the availability of sufficient real case data is difficult. Zhang et al. [44] train OSVM on falls and runaways from non-case ADL and show that falls can be effectively detected. Yu et al. [45] propose to train Fuzzy OSVM on fall activities captured by video cameras, and to optimize parameters based on falls and some non-case activities. Their method assigns blurred membership to different training samples to reflect their importance in classification and shows that they perform better than OSVM. Yu et al. [46] introduce a video-based fall detection system for older people. They extract multiple video functions and apply OCC techniques to determine whether falls are centered or located in new instances of OSVM, such as the ability to centralize or to test for new instances of fall.

sections.heading: 4.2. Insufficient data for falls
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Sampling Techniques
sections.text: In some situations, few real falls may be available during the training phase (see taxonomy (II) a in Figure 1). In these cases, Stone and Skubic [14] represent a two-stage fall detection system. In the first stage, the vertical state of a person is characterized in individual depth frame frames, followed by an ensemble of decision trees to calculate confidence in the occurrence of a fall. The data they collect have a fall ratio of 1: 400 compared to normal activities. They support normal activities s.t. The ratio is reduced to 1: 40 and forms a decision tree ensemble. The activities examined in their analysis are standing, sitting and lying positions, close (within 4 m) to far-falling locations, and occur in comparison to non-occurring falls and report better results compared to standard methods. Debard et al. [32] Falls represent an actual use where the data collected for the weighted areas of the M-balance are not weighted.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Semi-Supervised Techniques
sections.text: Manual tagging of activities can be very cumbersome, tedious and time-consuming. In most cases, in addition to some labeled data, there is a wealth of unlabeled data; such a case requires the introduction of semi-supervised methods for detecting falls (see Taxonomy (II) b in Figure 1). Liu et al. [49] present a semi-supervised learning mechanism based on surveillance to detect falls and other ADLs to overcome the exhaustive labeling of human activities, using spatial field constraint energy to support SVM-based interaction decisions with a Bayesian inference model, followed by a semi-supervised step to retrain the classifier by automatically noting the activities with the highest confidence. However, their method is sensitive to environmental changes and needs to be retrained in new situations. Fahmi et al al al al al. [50] present a semi-supervised case monitoring method using smartphones, first developing a multifiltered algorithm based on medley decision-room, then a semi-based algorithm.

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Cost Sensitive Classification and Decision Theory
sections.text: The problem of lack of recognition is a good example of unbalanced learning methods, because the data for normal activities is easy to collect and sufficiently available compared to other cases. Traditionally maintained algorithms, however, expect balanced datasets to be dominated by the majority class. In order to deal with unbalanced classes, these algorithms will not be able to represent characteristics of the data and provide unfavorable accuracies when presented with unbalanced datasets [54], and their predictions can be dominated by the majority class. To deal with unbalanced classes, a cost-sensitive classification is carried out, in which the different costs in a classification are addressed problematically. This can be done either by presenting different cost matrix to a free classification or by changing the inner workings of a classification.

sections.heading: 5. Detecting Falls in the Absence of their Training Data
sections.text: In a realistic environment, due to the lack of sufficient data for falls and the lack of knowledge and understanding of what these falls might be, approaches for detecting outliers / abnormalities (see Taxonomy (II) d in Figure 1) and single-class classifications (see Taxonomy (II) e in Figure 1) can be used. These techniques cannot directly identify falls because case samples are not available to classifiers during the training phase; however, they can indirectly identify falls as abnormal (or non-normal) activity. In these approaches, deviations from normal behavior are labeled as abnormal activity. Falls are one of the most common abnormal activities; therefore, such techniques can be adapted for detecting falls. However, the concept of normal activity must be clearly defined because any abnormal activity may not be a fall. If the data of normal activity is insufficient, then such techniques may cause excessive false alarms; however, new research shows that we can only identify them as normal falls based on [63, 65] or that they can be studied in models that are not in the past.

sections.heading: 5.1. Studies on Detecting Falls as Anomalies
sections.text: In fact, most people are able to decide for themselves what they want and what they want.

sections.heading: 5.2. Studies on Anomaly Detection not Specifically Focused on Fall Detection
sections.text: We discussed in Section 3 that fall detection methods in Category (II) (see taxonomy (II) d and (II) e in Figure 1) do not directly detect falls because either the training data for falls is insufficient or is missing during training. In such a scenario, a plausible approach is to identify a fall as an abnormal activity (or anomaly) that we discussed in the above section. Alternatively, several methods for detecting abnormal activity that are not specific to fall detection can also be adapted so that a fall can be identified as one of the abnormal activity or anomaly. Now, we are reviewing several abnormal activity detection techniques that collect data from either vision-based or portable sensors; only require training data from normal activities to learn the models and be able to identify abnormal activities. These methods may very well be adapted to the task of fall detection.

referenceMentions.context: Research in activity recognition has led to the successful realization of intelligent pervasive environments that can provide context, assistance, monitoring and analysis of a subject’s activities that are usually backed up by advanced machine learning and vision algorithms [1, 2, 3].

Research in activity recognition has led to the successful realization of intelligent pervasive environments that can provide context, assistance, monitoring and analysis of a subject’s activities that are usually backed up by advanced machine learning and vision algorithms [1, 2, 3].

Research in activity recognition has led to the successful realization of intelligent pervasive environments that can provide context, assistance, monitoring and analysis of a subject’s activities that are usually backed up by advanced machine learning and vision algorithms [1, 2, 3].
Falling is one of the most common type of abnormal activity and the most studied [4, 5].
Falling is one of the most common type of abnormal activity and the most studied [4, 5].
In real life, most falls are caused by a sudden loss of balance due to an unexpected slip or trip, or loss of stability during movements such as turning, bending, or rising [6].
According to the WHO report [8], the frequency of falls increase with an increase in age and frailty.
Older people living in nursing homes fall more often than those living in the community (around 30 − 50%) and 40% of them experience recurrent falls [8].
fall incidences more accurately [9].
Experiencing a fall may lead to a fear of falling [5], which in turn can result in lack of mobility, social isolation, less productivity and can increase the risk of a fall.
The rarity of occurrence of falls lead to a lack of sufficient data for them for training the classifiers [11].
Alternatively, artificial fall data can be collected in controlled laboratory settings; however, that may not be the true representative of actual falls [12].
However, the fall data generated from such experiments will still be skewed towards normal activities [14] and it is difficult to develop generalizable classifiers to identify falls efficiently.
[15] report a short review on fall detection with an emphasis on the physics behind a fall, methods used to detect a fall and evaluation criteria based on statistical analysis.
Yu [16] presents a survey on approaches and principles of fall detection for elderly patients.

[17] present a survey on real-time fall detection methods based on techniques that measure only the acceleration, techniques that combine acceleration with other methods, and techniques that do not measure acceleration.
[18] present a survey on fall detection and monitoring ADL and categorize them into vision based, ambient-sensor based and kinematic-sensor based approaches.
[4] present another survey on fall detection methods with an emphasis on different systems for fall detection and their underlying algorithms.
Delahoz and Labrador [19] present a review of the state-of-the-art in fall detection and fall prevention systems along with qualitative comparisons among various studies.
[20] present a systematic review of fall detection techniques using wearable sensors.
[21] present a survey of research papers that exclusively use

[22] present another review for automatic fall detection by categorizing the existing platforms based on either wearable and ambient devices, and the classification methods are divided into rule-based and machine learning techniques.
[5] review 327 research papers on fall detection and categorize them as either context-aware systems or wearable devices (including smartphones).
[23] present a review of fall detection methods from the perspective of use and application of technology designed to detect falls and alert for help from end-user and health and social care staff.

[31] present another survey on the analysis of android based smart phones solutions for fall detection.

• It is noted in many of the above survey papers that techniques based on fixed thresholds on sensor readings, though simple to implement and computationally inexpensive, are very hard to generalize across different persons and does not provide a good trade-off between false positives and false negatives [5].
A fall is a rare event that can occur in diverse ways [32]; therefore, collecting sufficient fall data is very difficult.
A long term experiment is required to glean real falls; however, such an experiment may only result in very few samples for real falls [14, 32].

[46] introduce a video-based fall detection system for elderly people.
[47] propose to use wireless signal propagation by employing the time variability and special diversity of Channel State Information as the indicator of human activities.

Firstly a local outlier factor algorithm [48] is used to filter out dynamic activities such as walking, sitting, standing up and falling and then an OSVM is trained on fall activities to distinguish it from other normal activities.
Stone and Skubic [14] present a two-stage fall detection system.
[32] use a weighted SVM to handle the imbalance in the dataset obtained for real world falls and normal activities from camera.
[49] present a vision based semi-supervised learning mechanism for detecting falls and other ADL to overcome the exhaustive labelling of human activities.

[50] present a semi-supervised fall detection method using smartphones by first training a supervised algorithm using decision trees, then using fall profiles to develop a semi-supervised algorithm based on multiple thresholds.

[51] present a nearest neighbour based semi-supervised fall detection method for smartphones that can be personalized and updated easily as a new user records new ADL and the system is retrained on the fly.
[52] present a 3D semi-supervised fall detection system that uses a monocular camera and uses an expert to refine an initially created small subset of labelled activity samples.
[53] present a semi-supervised approach to detect near-miss falls for ironworkers.

However, these algorithms fail to represent characteristics of the data and provide unfavourable accuracies when presented with imbalanced dataset [54], and their predictions may be dominated by the majority class [55].

To handle imbalanced classes, cost-sensitive classification is performed [54], where the main idea is to treat different costs in a classification problem
However, such costs are mostly unknown and hard to compute [11].
[56] perform cost-sensitive analysis for fall detection using Bayesian minimum risk and the Neyman-Pearson method.

[69] propose an unsupervised acoustic fall detection system with interference suppression that makes use of the features extracted from the normal sound samples, and constructs an OSVM model to distinguish falls from non-falls.
They show that in comparison to Popescu [68], their interference suppression technique makes the fall detection system less sensitive to interferences by using only two microphones.
[62] propose to identify falls using a smartphone as a novelty from the normal activities and find that OCNN performs better than OSVM but is outperformed by supervised SVM.
[63] evaluate fall detection methods that do not require fall data during training on different datasets collected using smartphone accelerometers.
Khan et al [64] present two ‘XFactor’ HMM approaches that are like normal HMMs, but have inflated output covariances that can be used as alternative models to estimate the parameters of unseen falls.
Kosuge [71] propose a method for a real-time visual state classification of a user with a walking support system.

[73] present a fall detection method using video feeds by tracking the person’s silhouette and performing shape analysis.

metadata.abstractText: A fall is an abnormal activity that occurs rarely; however, missing to identify falls can have serious health and safety implications on an individual. Due to the rarity of occurrence of falls, there may be insufficient or no training data available for them. Therefore, standard supervised machine learning methods may not be directly applied to handle this problem. In this paper, we present a taxonomy for the study of fall detection from the perspective of availability of fall data. The proposed taxonomy is independent of the type of sensors used and specific feature extraction/selection methods. The taxonomy identifies different categories of classification methods for the study of fall detection based on the availability of their data during training the classifiers. Then, we present a comprehensive literature review within those categories and identify the approach of treating a fall as an abnormal activity to be a plausible research direction. We conclude our paper by discussing several open research problems in the field and pointers for future research.
